For it is the nature os nitro-aerial particles when set in motion to produce a ruddy colour in the substances in which they are, as happens in spirit of nitre, which is ruddy during distillation.

It is to be noted here that as nitro-a'e'rial particles cause the fermentation ol the blood, so this fermenta· tion strikes out, in the way shown above, and draws from the air other nitro-aerial particles by which fer· mentation goes on anew in the blood. In fact nitro- aerial spirits, when mixed with the mass of the blood in the lungs, produce an intense enough effervescence in it; but they are soon separated for the most part from the blood in the system of the body, for purposes to be explained below, so that the fermentation of the blood on its return to the lungs is for want of thern much diminished and more sluggish; but still it does not cease so completely as to be unable to draw nitro-aerial particles from the air for its renewal. And so in fine the movement ol fermentation is per· petuated in the animal Automaton.

Just as the fermentation ol the blood, so also its heat arisesI think from the effervescence of nitro-a'e'rial particles with the saline-sulphureous particles of the blood.
